peopleAlsoAsk.question: What is an antique wash basin called?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: Eighteenth century In its 18th-century form the washstand was called a basin stand or basin frame, and is still sometimes described as a washhand stand. Its direct, but remote, ancestor was the monastic lavabo, ranges of basins of stone, lead or marble fed from a cistern (tank).
peopleAlsoAsk.title: Washstand - Wikipedia

peopleAlsoAsk.question: What is the difference between a wash basin and a wash sink?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: A sink is typically larger and found in kitchens and utility areas, used for tasks like washing dishes, while a washbasin tends to be smaller and located in bathrooms for washing your hands and face. At the end of the day though, both provide you with an essential function.
peopleAlsoAsk.title: What is the difference between sink and washbasin? - Bluecera LLP

peopleAlsoAsk.question: What is a bowl and pitcher set called?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: A pitcher and basin is usually just called a pitcher and basin. The cabinet that the pieces go on is a washstand.
peopleAlsoAsk.title: What is a pitcher and basin called? - Questions & Answers - 1stDibs

peopleAlsoAsk.question: What were pitchers and basins used for?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: Before indoor plumbing, every home had a basin and water pitcher for washing up. Our old-fashioned set carries on that tradition. Each stoneware piece is hand turned on a pottery wheel.
